text:
Indian food is crazy complicated, also you need to have a million different spices or blends on hand, both fresh and dried.. 
Just getting a random massala mix from your local (non Asian) supermarket really won't do. Also because there's reason and rhyme as to how and when you add those individual spices, which is kind of impossible to do when everything is already ground up into a powder.
Cooking good Indian food requires a lot of dedication and a family teaching you the basics and the secret family recipes and spice combinations.

text: The reason Italian food is so simple to make and has been considered pretty cheap food in Europe for a long time (that‚Äôs part of why it‚Äôs become so popular) is because Italia really wasn‚Äôt a rich country until about 50 years ago. The traditional food from there that got exported abroad is the food poor people would eat (pizza, pasta‚Ä¶) and was really cheap to buy even in the neighboring countries. Basically wheat flour and water with olive oil, cheese and sometimes tomatoes, with a lot of fat and/or starch ; the kind of stuff that gives you fuel for a day‚Äôs work, with ingredients rural Italians could basically pick up in their backyard. To this day pizza is still one of the foods with the lowest production cost in Europe. It‚Äôs insane that it gets sold for such high prices. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it tastes delicious. But you can‚Äôt deny that it‚Äôs both extremely simple and really cheap to make

text:
So far best chicken alfredo i've had (from a restaurant) has not been from olive garden. Or cheesecake factory (25$$ for just the noodles???? 30$$$ FOR THE CHICKEN???????) 
But
Rather: jasons deli. 12$ ish with garlic bread, and access to ice cream at the end. Creamy, yummy, well seasoned, and doesnt separate before you even eat it, OLIVE GARDEN. 

Other ones were this small brunch place, where i think it was like 17$ but small business + big portion + i wasnt paying = worth it. 

And 
By far
My favorite one that lives in my dreams: this small diner inside the Silver Nugget in Reno Nevada. Only reason i'd go back to reno. It was THAT GOOD. I miss it so much. 

Anyway
The point is- italian is COMFORT food. It should be AFFORDABLE!!! 

And Indian is amazing. I absolutely understand why it costs so much. Worth it. I'd pay 25$ for a meal at a good indian place.

text: So basically you're whining because italian food in the U.S. is overpriced... The thing you call italian food in the U.S. isn't italian food, Americans are well known for butchering recipes from the rest of the world using random ingredients, as you did in the video. Like, come on, I can accept cashews in the pesto but cooking pasta in the juices of a charred chicken? There are 20 regions in Italy, and each one of them has at least 3 great regional dishes; just think about frico, polenta, focaccia, fiorentina, arrosticini, arancini, olive ascolane, cannoli, gelato, tiramisu, and none of them is pasta. Try pulling out that many regional dishes in the U.S. You can't, because the only American foods that come to mind are hot dogs, hamburgers (both from Germany) and FRENCH fries. It's like asking my grandma for her favourite pok√®mon, she just knows Pikachu. If the other typical foods cost less it's not our fault, here in Italy a pizza, a kebab, a sushi dinner or a curry chicken all have nearly the same price.

text: People like to sh*t on american food. But there is so much good things other than Burgers: Creole and Cajun / Louisiana cuisine, lobster and oysters and clam chowder in New England, Florida/ Caribbean shrimp dishes, California with fresh salads and vegetables. And then of course Smoked Brisket and the many styles of BBQ / Barbecue, from Texas to Memphis to the Carolinas and the many different styles of sauces (bourbon infused, mustard based NC style...), not to mention food immigrants brought to the USA from Poland Russia Mexico Ireland... There is great food and variation in America. I personally prefer Korean and Japanese food over Italian food, and I lived in Sicily and miss their pastries and seafood, but pasta is actually pleasant food... Creative ways to improve cheap carbs and use local ingredients. In my opinion the Greek and Turkish cuisine is superior as well

text:
Italian here.
- italian cuisine is regarded globally as the best in the entire world (some people say it‚Äôs French, still italian food is in the top 2). 
- Traditional italian cuisine is simple, but delicious for the supreme quality of the ingredients. Cooking what you call ‚Äúitalian food‚Äù in the US is not the same as you have crappy ingredients 
- How can you study in italy and claim Italian food is just pasta. Food is such a huuuuge part of our culture that travelling from one region to another (or more often than not one city to another in the same region) you will find widely different foods, recipes, and ingredients.
- Fine italian cuisine is sofisticated. Of course simple pasta al pesto is not ‚Äúfine dining‚Äù, nobody in italy thinks it is. It should tell you how much our cuisine is appreciated abroad, that a simple ‚Äúpoor‚Äù dish is such highly regarded.
- what you are making in the video is an actual abomination. Nobody eats chicken as a topping for pasta in italy, and don‚Äôt even get me started on that butter and cream sauce you mixed with the Pesto sauce. It is obvious you know nothing about italian cuisine, so before spouting nonsense like this again, maybe make sure you know what you are talking about first üòâ

text: ¬†@kdjoshi726¬† No offense, but if you do not come from a certain culture, why would you think you know so much about its food? Unless you live in Italy, you haven't gotten into contact with authentic Italian cuisine and all its diverse dishes and preparations. You can't compare the degree of complexity of the Indian and Italian breakfast based on the use of spices...
author: @gnamorfra

text: ¬†@zoeyyue¬† The point is that if you're Chinese and have not spent a significant time of your life in Italy or know deeply the culture you most certainly do not know the Italian cuisine that well. Obviously there are quick pasta dishes, like I'm sure there are quick Chinese noodles dishes...
author: @gnamorfra

text: ¬†@gnamorfra¬† of course there are time consuming Italian dishes. I also made lasagna and pizza from scratch and of course I couldn't know it all like an Italian, but I still suggest you to explore other cuisine a little bit more. Btw I live in Belgium and have been to many European countries and several times to Italy and I love it. I also followed several Italian chefs to learn the cooking. With all the respect, it is one of the easy to make cuisine.
author: @zoeyyue

text: ¬†@zoeyyue¬† I've traveller and lived abroad myself, too, and I love eating non-Italian food. Travelling doesn't necessarily give you a deep and thorough insight into another culture's cuisine, though... Actually knowing another country's food culture takes a lot more than that. Everyone here keeps on mentioning pasta, now you mention pizza, which are obviously very common dishes in Italy, but there's a myriad of other dishes much more complex and time consuming than those. Keep in mind that the Italian cuisine is regional, so even though it's a relatively small country, it's quite diverse. For example, it spans from Germanic and Slavic inspired food to the Arabic inspired couscous, traditional in Sicily.
author: @gnamorfra

text: ‚Äã¬†@Cheffe919¬† Even a dosa needs to be like.. make the batter. If it's too much salt it tastes bad if it's less it's manageable but bad. You have to make it perfect and you have to be standing in the kitchen for 2 hours for even to make dosas for 3 people. Because yea.. it's good. And it takes time.

text: ¬†@Archana_Manoj09¬† And the same goes for the Italian breakfast, if you were to make everything from scratch. All these comments imply that the Indian cuisine is somehow much more complex than the Italian one, but how much do you actually know about it? And I'm not talking about the Italian American cuisine, the one you can see in this video...

text: ¬†@gnamorfra¬†you‚Äôre not getting it. A basic Indian dish is ten times more complex than a basic Italian dish. In Indian food, there‚Äôs really no such thing as basic. I basic Italian tomato sauce say is 3 ingredients max anyone can make, a basic curry is still a dozen ingredients at least and skill.
author: @BB25_25

text: ¬†@BB25_25¬† The point is not whether a simple Indian dish is "ten time mote complex" than an Italian simple dish. You're comparing apples to oranges... Picking the easiest Italian dish, the classic tomato sauce, and comparing to the Indian curries. I'm not saying the Italian cuisine doesn't have simple dishes, all cuisines have them. I'm saying that's not what it's all about, there are elaborate, time and skill requiring dishes too. Many Italian dishes are not even much known outside the region they're traditional in, so why do you think you're such an expert about another culture's food?
author: @gnamorfra

text: ¬†@gnamorfra¬† actually that is the point. You want to compare a complex Italian dish to a basic Indian dish and then say Italian food is just as complex, when as a whole it isn‚Äôt. Italian food is more about the ingredients, Indian food is about the spices and layering flavours.
author: @BB25_25

text: ¬†@BB25_25¬† Of course in the Italian cuisine the quality of ingredients is key. But the point is that you're using a metre of evaluation of complexity that is valid for your own cultural food, and not for mine. If an Italian dish is complex, it isn't because it uses spices, but because it might call for specific skills or techniques most do not have, rare or expensive produce or products, it might be extremely time requiring, and so on. The simplicity you're referring to means we do not go overboard as the Americans often do, not that our cuisine is "basic". It is fine if you do not know all about it, in the end it's not your culture. But please respect it.

text: ¬†@davidebriguglio9925¬†I live in France and here pasta is 100% considered a side dish. You either eat it with meat or fish or something, or with a more or less elaborate sauce. Nobody eats dry pasta on its own. Moreover in Italy there isn‚Äôt one dish in a traditional meal but two. Antipasti, pasta, then the main dish, and then the dessert (Italian people pls correct me if I‚Äôm wrong). Pasta is not the only thing you eat. Your actual main dish is going to be meat or something more consistent. Pasta is effectively a side dish, like, a secondary one that you eat in between the starter course and the main course. Nowadays the most common way to eat pasta abroad is as a main course with just a sauce, but it‚Äôs still a side dish. The sauce is what gives it its flavor ; pasta on its own isn‚Äôt very interesting. As a kid and still to this day I‚Äôd mainly have pasta with steak and/or fish and without sauce. Just like the way I‚Äôd have potatoes or rice.

¬†@davidebriguglio9925¬† I am saying you  have a limited and very Euro-centric sense of history, and that Italians getting butthurt over people using and modifying their dishes- not even attributed recipes to a single person having a copyright violation- is hypocritical. 

Marinara sauce is the tomato sauce attributed to the Italians afaik and there's many variations even within the culture re: carrots, basil, etc; tomato sauce is simply tomatoes used as a sauce. Y'all didn't invent it, and yet the Italians believe they can police others on its usage. Italians need to stay out of other people's dishes and kitchens- it is basic anthropology that once anything leaves the culture of origin, it changes and evolves. Italians literally do it to sushi and many other foods themselves, and then get mad when others do the same lol. Let people eat food and be happy. Most other cultures understand and accept this.

text:
¬†@davidebriguglio9925¬† idk how to explain it better. 

Italians claim others "steal" and change their dishes, and that's "bad." Most of Italian cuisine was "stolen" and changed from other dishes, and that's... good? Also, Italy's international cuisine in Italy is changed to suit Italian tastes (without any of those bull "Italian-Japanese fusion" disclaimers they expect everyone to use on their food, they just call it Japanese,) and that's somehow fine, too. 

The hypocrisy is stunning and they need to take several seats. Food is food. There's no room for snobbishness. I've eaten at many Michelin restaurants and I tend to prefer other foods personally, and that's fine.

Also the "ancient foods of Italy" is bull because Italy is very young, and it's nonsense to use that to police others. No worries about following tradition for yourself, but don't put that on other people. I acknowledge that the regions that make up Italy and a few others have kept up with some dishes, but weaponizing it is a bad move.

text:
As an Italian (from Tuscany not from New Jersey): italian food is not overrated, it's overpriced.
In Italy a good serving of pasta in a common restaurant it's going to cost less than ‚Ç¨10 (about the same in dollars), of course we have some pricey places here as well, but still it could be ‚Ç¨15 or maximum ‚Ç¨20.
$30 is crazy: our cuisine is considered good all over the world so it probably deserves the title, but it's also as simple as it can be (for the most), so nobody should pay that much to enjoy our food.

text: ‚Äã¬†@holycrapdude123¬†This video and many comments are based on the assumptions that the cost of a meal depends on how "complicated" it is to prepare it. What you pay for is fresh and good ingredients. Sushi is literally a slice of raw fish on top of a rice ball, using the same logic it should be the cheapest food...
author: @kaladze93

text: ¬†@mirabilis¬† In the video it's implied that Indian food should be more expensive because there are way more ingredients involved, which makes economic sense. So Italian food should be cheaper because it's relatively simple. But its simplicity is exactly why people travel from all over the world to Italy just to eat the food, and also why the most popular food in the world is Italian. I've ordered simple contorni in Italy like sauteed spinach which is up there with some of the best food I've ever put in my mouth. And you're left wondering how it can be so different from any spinach you've ever had. In Italy, food is relatively cheap because the ingredients are simple and local, but because of that simplicity they also often make sure it's of extremely high quality. If you're getting Italian food in the USA you're also not really having the same experience as Italy is famous for not exporting their top products (like their best olive oils, wines, meats and cheeses) because food and restaurants are so crucial to their tourism industry (again because some people go there just to eat). So while I agree Italian cooking isn't always that complicated or requiring that many ingredients and is therefore often overpriced (mostly outside of Italy), I think it's a stretch to say the quality of Italian cuisine is overrated, especially if you're there and having the real experience.

text: Biryani, Tandoori Chicken, Naan, Butter Chicken, Chicken Tikka Masala, Paneer Tikka masala, Samosas, Dal, Aloo Gobi, Chole Bhature, masal Dosa, Palak Paneer, Malai Kofta, Gulab Jamun, Jalebi, Chaat. These are just a few dishes that (when done correctly) can easily outclass any Italian dish. Although Italian food was undeniably influenced by the Renaissance era and the Roman empire, it was only fully established in the late 1700‚Äôs. Italy was a fully unified country in the 1800‚Äôs thus the culture of individual city-states got lost. India, on the other hand, maintained most of its culture, due to it being unified in a much later, much more forgiving era. The vast history of India also makes its food much more diverse than Italian cuisine. Although taste is subjective, generalizing Indian cuisine represents your ignorance of the vast history and diversity of dishes.

text:
¬†@WokeSlapper¬† 99% of so called "Italian restaurants" abroad are not proper Italian restaurants... For many reasons also Italian kitchen is not competitive in price since the quality and the origin of the ingredient is crucial. Try to compare a real mozzarella from Campania to an American one....
The semplicity of our dishes makes them even more difficult to make properly good, most of the times if you don't have the proper ingredients, follow the right technique and recipe you have a very far result than what it supposed to be. 
I am telling you this since I have been living abroad for years, me and my friends cooked in front of people of all around the world and everytime they can't believe how much meticulousness we put into cooking a "simple" dish.

text: Some people will not want to admit it, but Italian food is romanticised in the rest of the western world because it comes from Europe. Indian and other "ethnic" cuisine is not from a predominantly white culture so the expectation is that it must be cheap, as the inference is that ethnic food is inferior to euro cuisine. This isn't a reflection on Italian food or even Italian people. Its also not to say that "gourmet" indian or other ethnic food isn't a thing (it's usually a gentrification issue). People have their stereotypes. Imo, all cuisine is equally precious.

text:
Here's something to consider, for all the "authentic Italian food" purists in the comments:

Tomato is one of the most prevalent ingredients in the so-called Italian cuisine even though it originates from The Americas. Isn't it hilariously ironic that if Italian people back then were as narrow-minded as modern purists, the "aUtHeNtIc ItAlIaN cUiSiNe‚Ñ¢" wouldn't exist today?

Funnily enough, the first Italian to use tomato as a food ingredient could possibly be called an Italian-American (of course the entity we call Italy today wouldn't exist for another several hundred years anyway).

Secondly, how can there be an authentic Italian cuisine when the traditional cuisine of e.g. Sicily and Northern Italy have little relation to each other? 

Note: this is not an attack towards Italians but criticism against purism in general.

They made it easier to pay online later on, and although it was a tiny bit buggy he at least kept me able to get lunch. text: I'm Italian. Grew up and lived in Italy my whole life and saying Italian food is just pasta is EXTREMELY reductive. Italian cuisine can't be chalked up to 1 item only, and traditional Italian food varies A LOT from region to region. Pasta is a big thing here don't get me wrong, but it's not all there is, and while simplicity is the way to make a lot of pasta dishes, that doesn't apply to Italian cuisine as a whole. Now, i understand your argument and i agree that it'd better to learn how to cook pasta yourself instead of spending a lot of money on it as far as "authenticity" of traditional Italian food goes in the US, i'm just pointing this out.

text: Italian food is very simple in that there are usually few ingredients. As such, there is really nowhere for them to hide behind strong spices or flavors, so the quality and freshness of the ingredients is paramount. This makes sense, since Italy has an incredible climate and culture for growing quality vegetables and spices. Yes, cheap boxed, dried pasta and jar sauce will be fine but nothing incredible. Homemade sauce with fresh, quality tomatoes and pasta made from scratch is lightyears ahead.

text:
¬†@tweakypoppy¬† First, good food isn't necessarily about complicated preparations.
Second Italian food has some very complicated dishes, just that usually it's more about the preparations of the ingredients themselves, than the actual dish.
Third, that guy only talked about pasta in America and its price which is absolutely out of place when talking about Italian pasta in restaurants, which in my experience is max 10 euros.
He said he studied in Italy, but doesn't know that the cost of dishes is based on the quality of the ingredients used and not only on the process of cooking...I wonder what he learned.
Italians do the most with the least amount of ingredients, it's all about skill and quality.
Above all, the guy put burnt chicken on top of pasta and minced the pesto in an electric chopper, you'll never see that in Italy.
It's like he's doing this on purpose to spite Italians, plus comparing Indian food with Italian food, is like comparing Mexican with Japanese, they don't have anything to do with each other.
author: @laurajanco2i

text: ¬†@laurajanco2i¬† He's a professional cook, I think he does.
author: @tweakypoppy

text:
¬†@tweakypoppy¬† Even Gordon Ramsey is a professional cook, but was criticized by a Thai chef, because his Pad Thai wasn't actual Pad Thai.
As someone who lives in Italy, has tasted Italian food for my whole life and has cooked it since I was a teen, I can tell you that it's not "how complicated a dish is", that makes Italian food good.
The best Italian dishes are the simple ones.
Pasta is also the most common Italian dish... one can make it almost everyday, just with olive oil and a bit of Parmiggiano cheese (which isn't Parmesan).
Pasta with tomato sauce or cheese wouldn't obviously be that complex to make.
It depends on what quality of pasta you use, what pasta dish you make and what type of ingredients you use.
Being a good cook also doesn't mean necessarily that you know the nuances, traditions and culture of another country's cuisine as well as they do, or that you're an expert in their cuisine.
You might know how to cook a dish like pasta, but do you know how to prepare it in the correct way? Are the ingredients to make your dish fresh? Where do you buy the ingredients? Do you make/grow/farm/brew/season them yourself? How? How much quantity do you use? Which methods do you use? Do you use too much seasoning, or do you know how to cook so you can take advantage of the food's properties? Etc...
This is not America, even our supermarket food isn't processed the same way.
It's not just about "how many steps this dish has compared the other recipe", or about being fancy, which in my opinion is the reason why Italian food is so good.
author: @laurajanco2i

text: ‚Äã¬†@tweakypoppy¬†he has no idea how Italian food is made, and how it taste. You too probably.

text: Crafting authentic Italian and Indian dishes like Spaghetti Carbonara and Butter Chicken with high-quality ingredients reveals a fascinating cost comparison: $12.17 for Carbonara and $8.50 for Butter Chicken. This highlights that while both cuisines value quality, their ingredient costs vary. Italian dishes often require pricey imports, whereas Indian cuisine's complexity comes from its spices. Despite the differences, both emphasize that investing in premium ingredients is key to an enhanced culinary experience, showcasing the rich diversity of global food traditions in a nutshell.

text: It's popular as fine dining (in the US, I mean) basically because the boomers were contradicting their parents, who saw French cuisine as the standard "high end" dining. At the time, most Italian migrants in the US were poor. (And I'm not saying this to disparage Italians or anything, just explaining the perception from that time). So basically, US boomers took the food that was viewed as lowly or too simple, and made that their fine dining experience.

text: There are definitely Italian foods that are less simple and more akin to ‚Äòfine dining‚Äô. Definitely one of my favourite cuisines (I‚Äôm Dutch and the Dutch cuisine itself is‚Ä¶ mostly unremarkable). Still there are other great cuisines. text:
¬†@jazzycakes6294¬†Well honestly, for a fancy sit down restaurant ingredients are a very minor part of the cost, usually around 20%.
In a Fancy restaurants you can only sell a table perhaps twice an evening, and there's a lot of wages to pay.
So no matter how cheap the ingredients they cant sell a main dish for $10, the average check has to be a certain amount.
Now, in Montreal where I lived for a while there is a place making killer pastas with high quality ingredient for cheap, I used to go there all the time. The Secret? there was no table service and a very limited selection of daily pastas, people got handed their portion at the counter and were expected to eat eat quickly for lunch, they can sell hundreds of portions a day in a small space, the menu is limited so no need for too many cooks and because the ingredients are not too expensive they can sell a hearty portion of delicious pastas for CAD 10.

text:
The entire video is a demonstration of good Italian food NOT being easy to make, especially making the base for the sauce. I might as well just buy ragu and really save on time.

Freshly made pasta with a really good sauce is sublime. It's inviting to every palate. Same thing with pizza. There's a reason why Italian food is a thing in most nonwestern countries of the world, while Indian food (which has its own merits) isn't. 

Pasta can be expensive, but the trick is to bring the leftovers home, dump some more pasta on it, and have a second meal. Most Italian places are never stingy with the sauce. I also take the bread home.
author: @j95lee

text:
Italian cuisine is dead last for me. Had plenty of Italian food at the best restaurants in the US and Italy, I will never voluntarily get or make Italian food when you could get Indian, Thai, Chinese, Mexican, or any of another dozen cuisines that actually taste like something.

Not a big cheese guy, not a big bread guy. The standard American diet is more in line with the Italian palette, which is why it‚Äôs the most popular in the US. Half of ‚ÄòAmerican‚Äô food is just simplified Italian food. Italian food is much less popular outside of the US.

¬†@JRSpecht¬† I'm not here to say wither it's good or bad. Honestly people eat different things in different countries and I respect that. Like someone who mentioned Indian food, and yes I love Indian food, I love diversity and I wouldn't say one country is superior to others, much less my own. But the fact that he's talking about Italian food and being high and mighty of how it's overrated and how he learned how to cook from a real Italian Nonna and then does something we consider a faux pas in Italy is hypocrisy at the very least, disingenuous at it's worst, especially considering when your only dismerit to the a whole counties food is that it's expensive in NYC and you're only really looking at one specific part (pasta) and you still manage to fuck it up.

Tl;Dr don't listen to Italians who tell you that you have to cook one specific way, but at the same time don't take something that is completely wrong, call it Italian, and then shit on it for being bad.

text: ¬†@teggianosalerno5050¬† I don't know a ton about Italian food so forgive my ignorance but is it like some iron clad unbreakable rule that you should never serve chicken with pesto?
author: @artirony410

text: ‚Äã¬†@artirony410¬†italian cuisine enthusiasts are huge sticklers about adhering to classic recipes word for word, and surprisingly elitist for a cuisine that is this basic. What other culture could have gotten away with shaping small pieces of dough slightly differently and calling them different dishes?
author: @georgiykireev9678

text: @ykireev9678 And sometimes they're sticklers for things that aren't even traditional or original. Like the Italians who insist that real carbonara is made only with guanciale, never any other meat... when in fact the chef who invented it in 1944 (not centuries ago) used bacon from American military rations.
author: @andrewhcit

text:
this whole dish is wrong. Pesto isn't to be cooked, it shouldn't be served with meat, you shouldn't put chicken anywhere near pasta, you don't need tons of butter or cream or wine to cook something ecc. 
¬†@artirony410¬†
author: @pietrogallino9952

text: @georgiykireev9678¬† you're so wrong this isn't just an "italian cuisine enthusiast" thing this is literally how all cuisine works. Nobody cares if you change recipes, it's that restaurants and big companies market food as "italian food" when it isn't. Can I make a perogie and stuff it with ground beef onions pickles cheese and big mac sauce and call it Polish food? Sounds delicious but it's not Polish food. Things get slapped the Italian label because it sells...zesty italian salad dressing, italian seasoning, italian flavored cheeze it's...etc
author: @teggianosalerno5050

text: @artirony410¬† you can serve pesto with whatever the hell you please but don't call it Italian food. If I make shawarma with roasted pork and put pineapple inside of it is it right to call this middle eastern food? Is it even right to call it Shawarma? Of course it isn't.
author: @teggianosalerno5050

text: ¬†@teggianosalerno5050¬† it'd still be Polish inspired (or any East Slavic country, we just call them vareniki instead)
author: @georgiykireev9678

text: ¬†@georgiykireev9678¬† Yea but polish inspired is different from polish
author: @Hello-jh1rq

text: @georgiykireev9678¬† I agree it is Polish inspired but I dont think it would be right to open a restaurant fly the Polish flag everywhere and call it a Polish restaurant. We never see this, this is done all the time in the name of "Italian" food, from restaurants to products at the grocery store. This is why Italians are always worked up about it.
author: @teggianosalerno5050

text: ¬†@georgiykireev9678¬†most cultures are sticklers about recipes and their culture. If you‚Äôre going to ignore conventions and make your own thing why call it ‚ÄúItalian‚Äù cuisine? At that point say it‚Äôs inspired instead. Also it‚Äôs not just Italy, Jamie Oliver made it to Spanish news for his paella recipe, and people shit in others for messing up fried rice (and other recipes) pretty frequently.
author: @walkermorales337

text: ¬†@artirony410¬†It‚Äôs not so much about the chicken or the fact that you eat them in the same meal, is the fact that you don‚Äôt put stuff on top of pasta, because pasta is not bread or rice, the pasta is the dish, not a side, not something you eat combined with something else, pasta al pesto is the recipe, and grilled chicken is another one, you can have them both, but not on the same plate, one before (the pasta generally) and then the chicken (or the stew, or the grilled veggies, or the fried cod or whatever that is that you are gonna eat as second course)

author: @teggianosalerno5050

text:
‚Äã@andrewhcit carbonara was not invented in 1944. cacio e ova (carbonara without meat) is a centuries-old recipe from abruzzo, and roman jews have been making kosher carbonara (maybe not referring to it as carbonara) for about 100 years. 
"carbonara was invented during WWII" is one of the great myths about italian food along with "pasta came from china" (it did come from somewhere, not china though)

text: ¬†@tommasobianchi5496¬† ok so its just something completely arbitrary then

text:
¬†@teggianosalerno5050¬† I gather you're a fellow italian, a campano... which makes it even more ridiculous (e aggiungerei porcoddio) that you don't know what pizza is. 
pizza is just the dough at the base. And the name for a bunch of different things. pizza di scarola is pizza, pizza chiena is pizza, pizza fritta is pizza, the word pizza in italian has NEVER implied the presence of specific toppings. and pineapple pizza made by the most clueless american is still pizza. just awful pizza at that.

text:
It's over priced, but typically it's good when you get it. On the other hand other cuisines are more complicated to make often turn out tasting like garbage or completely inauthentic. For example, I travel to Thailand a few times a year on business and vacation etc for the past 20 years, and am familiar with the culture and food.  I went to my local Thai restaraunt and ordered the yellow curry, and out came red curry, or something like it. I said mentioned that my dish wasn't what I ordered and was scoffed at. I told her that I've been traveling around Thailand for the past 20 years and this isn't anything close to what yellow curry was. I mean it wasn't even yellow, no turmeric

Same thing when my Sharma place giving me a gyro and trying to call it a shawarma. I lived in the UAE for 13 years I know what a shawarma is. IMO these places with complex dishes often cheap out in ingredients, make in bulk so nothing is fresh, or simply charge an outrageous price for the good stuff that is on par with the $18 chicken parm. 

US citizens aren't too familiar with eating biryani or zatar and are more comfortable with eating familiar items, like items from western countries.

author: @hansmemling2311

text:
¬†@hansmemling2311¬† Its not just about cuisine - most European countries have great cuisine and those which don't can make up for it with innovation. Evidently things get more interesting the further south you go but all except perhaps the Netherlands and Scandinavia have exciting stuff to discover.

But its also just quality of the food and effort put into making good food in the average restaurant. Italian food can get really tiresome when you live there. Especially if you are not massively into carbs - but if I were, I would take Turkey over Italy. 

I have a feeling that there is a certain smugness to restaurants in Italy - you are in Italy so necessarily my cooking has to be good when objectively its not. But Im going to overcharge you anyways because 300 million Americans think Italian food is God's gift to humanity. 

I consider the most sophisticated and varied cuisine to be the Chinese, btw. Its a world to itself. And they really understand how to make pasta.
author: @ade910

text: ¬†@ade910¬†There are some countries that drag the European average down a whole lot. I‚Äôm European too (Dutch to be exact, our native foods are mostly unremarkable). text:
As an Italian I think that 99% of Italian restaurants outside Italy are not overrated, they are ABSOLUTE SHIT.
The thing is that what makes Italian cuisine (according also to American chefs) one of the best cuisines in the world are the INGREDIENTS. Now it is important to understand that

YOU CAN'T FIND ITALIAN INGREDIENTS OUTSIDE ITALY!!

Some of Italian ingredients like "Nduja", "Ricotta Salata", "Provolone del Monaco" etc... are hard to be found even in Italy (you have to go to specific regions).
In a nutshell NO, you CAN'T make homemade Italian food in the US. The dish in the video may be good but its not Italian.
After said that I love Chicago/NY style pizze, I cook the hamburger just like Gordon Ramsey, and I prefer Turkish to Italian cuisine ‚ù§

text: I can kind of answer the fine dinning question. Think of what American cuisine is. To most people they think hamburgers, hot dogs and BBQ but in reality a good majority of American cuisine is considered comfort food such as biscuits and gravy, chicken fried steak, grits, pot roasts, casserole, gumbo, jambalaya, cobbler pie, etc. Most of those foods are associated with the lower to middle class, African-American, and generally southern cultures which weren't know for it's "fine dining" but rather it's simple comfort and closeness at the dinner table. Most ethnic foods to Americans would be considered fine dining as it is vastly different in culture and overall cuisine and sometimes there is even a different dinner table behavior associated. Italian dining culture in America, for example, can have it's dinner etiquette traced from the Italian immigrants from the late 1800's to early 1920's and the whole Mafia thing associated with suit like business-ware.

text:
I love, love making pasta from scratch. The best.
That being said, there have been times when I go to upscale restaurants where they serve you subpar pasta and charge $40 just for pasta.
Some pastas are very easy easy to make.
Stuffed ones a bit more complicated.

But he's right when he compares it to Indian food (or other equally complex cuisines). French, Mexican, Thai, etc. also have complex dishes, and except for French, the rest are not priced upscale. 

But Italian pasta can be fine dining IF done right, which is not universally the case.

text:
What ON EARTH is that dish supposed to be?

This makes as much sense as a hotdog wrapped in a pizza dipped in peanut butter.

- You don't ever put a big piece of meat on top of the pasta, and pesto is a pasta sauce NOT a meat sauce.

- Pesto doesn't have lemon in it, but I guess that could be ok. However, why on earth are you mixing it with the meat sauce and cream?! This is an abomination. 

Start again. Do it like this:
1. Make the pesto (basil, pine nuts, cheese, olive oil, salt). Cook the pasta, mix it with the pesto and add some pasta water. Garnish with more parmigiano and basil if you want, have some bread to mop up the sauce. Enjoy.

2. In the mean time, make the chicken the way you did, that looks tasty. Make that same sauce with cream and cheese, it also looks fine. Maybe add a side of vegetables, and grab some bread to mop up the sauce. Enjoy this dish after you've finished the pasta.

Those are two separate dishes to be enjoyed separately one after the other (if you went to Italy you should know this).

text:
In where I live, pasta dishes in Italian restaurant are around $10-15 and that is expensive compared to local cuisine and most people will not eat Italian dishes frequently because of their price. You can eat Pad Kraprao with rice for only around $2 and it will get you more full than any pasta dishes although I don't really like it.

But if we talk about New York City, maybe $30-40 for pasta is fair due to rent cost and other things over there but for me it's too expensive. Here in where I live, you can eat somewhat decent steak at that price and steak should be much more expensive than pasta and that should be common sense. However, I can't really judge that because I never go to NYC but according to other comment maybe it's impossible to eat Italian food there in the same price as in where I live for obvious reason.

And I think it's fair to think that Italian food shouldn't be more expensive than Indian food, Indian foods are more difficult to cook and have many ingredient, however most French and Italian restaurant are build for more fine-dining-ish experience and they usually charge more.

text:
Well there is a lot to say here. I agree with you in some of the points you‚Äôve made.
First of all I think Americans have a distorted view of what italian food really is, they eat one time in Italy and they think that they know all about italian food. In Italy there are a lot of resturants that cook shitty food and a lot of strangers go there because these places are near tourist areas. And if you eat italian food in the US, it is generally adapted to the taste of americans (so basically it is not italian food anynore).
Having said that I agree that italian food is generally simple (by simple I mean there are few good quality ingredients) and still almost every video I watch of americans making italian food, they screw the fuck up. They always ruin the ingredients by adding 256181 other ingredients that are totally unecessary.
I absolutely agree with you that if I had to pay 30 dollars for a pasta with canned tomatoes I am going to eat indian food all of my life for 15 dollars.
Having said that I am not saying that italian food is the best in the world (that depends on what you like), I am just saying that I want to burn my eyes after seeing how you made that pasta

NO you're wrong 'ITALIAN' food isn't overrated, 'FOOD' is overrated. 
Seriously though calling a country's national cuisine overrated isn't really all that productive and it isn't the way we should judge food imo. To me it just stands out as an obnoxious way of trying to offend people as a type of attention-seeking behaviour (not necessarily saying this was your intent). I also find it kinda distasteful (bdump tsch) and honestly just disrespectful. 
EDIT: It's also just kinda silly since taste in food is as subjective as it gets, so trying to present a cuisine as objectively overrated just doesn't really work when people have wildly different tastes.

text:
As an italian cooking enthusiast:
1- italian are super defensive when comes to food, usually in a very toxic way. For example they go nuts if you experiment a little with something in a way that is subjectively wrong for them, it's a thing i really don't like. Maybe because someone takes it as a really serious matter, literally insulting you in a non ironical way.
2- i don't know why abroad italian cuisine is considered fine dining. I think that it's strenght is simplicity and being "folk". True traditional italian cuisine for me is making a giant batch of spaghetti for 20 people (but we are only 5) and eating on a plastic table in the garden, not some fine restaurant.
3- i am not a food nazi like other italians, but the thing you cooked in the video is not italian üòÇ (or at least is not a recipe i know of, but i never seen someone eating chicken with pasta). Sorry but probably we have food nazism in DNA, and i really cannot avoid telling you that, even if only a little. 
Anyway, in the end i think that we should only eat and cook how we please and experiment, it's good to have fun üòä (i, for example, defend pineapple on pizza. I said It. I don't like It, but of you like eat It and don't listen to anyone! Now i will probably be hunted for treason in my country, i have to go in exile)

text: ¬†@firstname3229¬† you know the whole "Italian don't add chicken on pasta" is because of how scarce chicken is at one point in Italy right? As a result, Italians are more used to pasta that doesn't use chicken in it because that how their Noona does it. It's basically you just doing it cos you see you grandma does it so you just follow not knowing why they do it just like seeing your grandma cut the end of a sausage and just following it not knowing she does it because she doesn't have a bigger pan to fit the whole sausage.  Case on point you can find multiple restaurants already putting chicken back into Pasta in Italy. Heck you don't even need to find a restaurant that does so just go look for a random house and you find a lot of people that either have cooked pasta with chicken in it or has eaten it at some point. After all thinking that no one has ever done something is pretty ridiculous especially when there has never been a rule whether you can have chicken on pasta.

text:
¬†@firstname3229¬† LA RICETTA DELLA DOMENICA | I FUSI CON LA GALLINA

Era un po‚Äô che nella mia dispensa girava un pacco di fusi _ pasta all‚Äôuovo tipica dell‚ÄôIstria, che si mangia spesso anche a Trieste.
E cos√¨ per questa domenica, mi √® venuto in mente di proporvi una vera leccornia, i fusi con la gallina, di cui i miei figli vanno pazzi.
Il sugo, un umido di gallina, √® ottimo anche con gli gnocchi.
I fusi, per quelli come me un po‚Äô pigri,  si possono trovare, sia in uno degli innumerevoli pastifici in giro per la citt√† sia comperare confezionati.
Io li trovo, ottimi, dalla mia fruttivendola di fiducia, la Dolly, in via Schiaparelli.

Ingredienti
(per il sugo)
Una gallina
Una cipolla
Uno spicchio d‚Äôaglio
olio extravergine d‚Äôoliva
Conserva di pomodoro q.b.
Un bicchiere di vino bianco secco
Acqua all‚Äôoccorrenza
Aromi dell‚Äôorto

(per i fusi)
3 uova
500 gr di farina
1 cucchiaio d‚Äôolio
uno spruzzo di vino bianco, al bisogno.

Preparazione
La gallina, che √® coriacea, va tagliata a piccoli pezzi. Io la faccio tagliare direttamente dal macellaio.
In una pentola _ una volta si usava il coccio _ fate un soffritto_ ‚Äúdisfritto‚Äù  _  di olio, aglio e cipolla. Qualcuno aggiunge anche del lardo, ma a me sembra un po‚Äô troppo.
Aggiungete la gallina a pezzi, il vino, che farete evaporare, la conserva di pomodoro e l‚Äôacqua. Aggiungete degli aromi, quelli che avete (rosmarino, salvia, santoreggia). Non troppi, mi raccomando e lasciate cuocere a fuoco bassissimo per almeno tre ore, regolando con l‚Äôacqua il sugo che dovr√† risultare un intingolo quasi colloso, dal colore bruno dorato.
Per essere ottimo l‚Äôumido di gallina andrebbe mangiato il giorno dopo.
I fusi li ho comperati gi√† fatti!
In ogni caso leggo da vari siti che i fusi si fanno impastando le uova con la farina. Niente sale, casomai un cucchiaio d‚Äôolio o un po‚Äô di vino. Bisogna lavorare vigorosamente e pazientemente l‚Äôimpasto in modo da ricavarne una pasta soda e liscia che va lasciata riposare per un‚Äôoretta prima di essere tirata a velo con il mattarello. Infine la pasta va tagliata in quadrati che si devono avvolgere di ‚Äúsbiego‚Äù attorno al manico di un cucchiaio di legno.
Per vedere le diverse fasi della lavorazione dei fusi vi segnalo il blog nuvole di farina
Cuocete i fusi e conditeli con il sugo di gallina.

Se non avete voglia di lavorare, a Trieste potete mangiare degli ottimi fusi sia da Suban che alla trattoria la Sorgente.
Le foto non sono mie. Le ho pescate su internet. Ringrazio gli ignoti autori

Here I give you a whole recipe so you can taste what your fellow Italian is cooking back in 2014

¬†@nabkill0134¬†we do not put chicken in pasta. End of story. It is not because we are poor, nor because we misunderstood our grandmas‚Ä¶ it is because culturally we do not mix those 2 ingredients, how many times do we have to tell you? 

Making bolognese with lamb or pasta with hen is different. Nobody makes chicken breast pasta üòÇ I am glad you feel close to Italian history and cuisine but you‚Äôve got this wrong, come visit us for a summer and we will very friendly convince you that chicken and pasta belong separate, across different regions.

text:
‚Äã¬†@nabkill0134¬†What is your source on this? At least I can claim to be living in Italy as an Italian for more than 20 years and demonstrate you that we don't put chicken in pasta, in any region I'm aware of. Also do consider that many dishes we eat today in the country either have a thousand or more years of history (like Lasagna), are from the 1600s (like Polenta, anything made with Tomatoes or Potatoes which also modified some other dishes) or are very very new additions to what is considered traditional like Carbonara, Tiramis√π which respectively come from the 50s and 80s.

In these periods the way of eating changed a lot but you can't really argue that we lacked chicken and thus we don't put in pasta, we've had a ton of sheep for millenias and we don't add it to pasta

text:
Indian food has always been seen as a lower tier because the notion of "gourmet" and "fine dining" is defined by Europeans, principally the French.  Indian food doesn't come close to fitting that mold, so it's inferior by default.  India is also an extremely high poverty nation, so virtually all Indian food is "peasant food", which means it's ineligible to be "gourmet' until you do something to elevate it.  What constitutes "elevating" the food?  Well, that's defined by Euro-centric culinary traditions!  It means nothing powerful, spicy, or prone to make you fart.  Granted, one thing Indian food has in its favor is the complexity and involved process of certain dishes (e.g. any biryani) as well as the obsequiously simple dishes that make pasta dishes look like a nightmare (e.g. sundal).

Yes, things have changed in the past couple of decades, and so there are "fine dining" Indian places all over the country now...  Chinese cuisine went through the same battle earlier and it's also more recognized than it was originally.  Numerous African nations are bringing their cuisine to light in the present day and there will be Ethiopian and Ghanaian fine dining restaurants in no time.  You'll be paying $40 for a Timatim Fitfit and $50 for a Jollof rice well before you make your Obe ate grilled cheese video with niter kibbeh as the grilling fat.

text: ¬†@bck187¬† well in most Central European countries and America, Japanese food is considered fancy and expensive.  I‚Äôm not sure what countries you‚Äôre talking about, but the most influential and important countries view Japanese food as a valuable delicacy .  I‚Äôm not sure if you‚Äôre Italian and you took offense to what I said, but I never said I didn‚Äôt like Italian food.  I‚Äôm saying that in Germany when you want expensive fancy food for a date, you often times eat at an Italian restaurant or a Japanese restaurant or a French restaurant.  In Japan, it would be odd and seem cheap to bring a first date to Italian food.  There are Italian restaurants everywhere here, and not very high quality, so people have grown to have a cheaper image of Italian food.
author: @timothyhofmeister-h6y

text:
¬†@timothyhofmeister-h6y¬† Japanese food is the most basic and unsophisticated food in the world.
just because you cut your fish with a samurai blade doesn't make it any better.
yes Japan has good seafood available, just serving it raw and with noodles and rice is nothing compared to other countries that cook it and add all the right herbs and spices.
author: @bck187

text: ¬†@bck187¬† you‚Äôre pretty much only listing rice and raw fish which is a very small portion of Japanese food.  That‚Äôs like me saying all Italians eat is pasta.  I‚Äôm not sure if your English is insufficient to understand what I‚Äôm saying.  I‚Äôm not talking about how delicious or Sophisticated food is.  I don‚Äôt care what foods you personally like or dislike, and I‚Äôm not talking about the foods that I do or don‚Äôt like.  I stated an objective fact.  That fact is that the majority of Central Europeans and North Americans VIEW japanese food as expensive, sophisticated, and fancy.  Most Americans also view Italian food the same way.  Objectively most japanese people VIEW Italian food as cheap and fast food.  I‚Äôm not talking about actual quality of food, or sophistication.  I‚Äôm speaking about the perspective and opinions of average people from different places.  I‚Äôm not saying Italian food is cheap, I‚Äôm saying that it‚Äôs viewed as cheap in japan.  Most of the Italians I know view Japanese food as fancy, so your opinion is the rare one that doesn‚Äôt correspond with normal average people.  And again because you don‚Äôt seem to be able to read and understand what I wrote, I‚Äôm only talking about the way food is viewed.  I love Italian food, and I wish more Japanese people found good quality Italian food, but I as a small insignificant person can‚Äôt change the way others think.  I‚Äôm only stating observations, not complaining about Italian food.  The only person doing that is you by trying to insult a specific type of food to make yourself feel better about my objective observation.
author: @timothyhofmeister-h6y

text: As an indian , i was in 5th class of middle school and due to circumstances had to live alone , after 5 days of surviving of just water i was blacking out and rushed to the kitchen snd scavenged a pack of noodles from there called maggi , since that day forward i kept lesrning new things to cook snd well after cooking for 6 yrs i can assure you indian food is very complex with all its different flavouring and methods and there isnt one correct way to cook many different dishes and the taste will differ from every region to region in india , but ofc the core for curries and many staple food remains the same and i have cooked many western dishes too but i must say they were way essier than even simplest daily main course meals here in india and i dont think i would ever eat bland food so i always add a touch of indian spices whenever i make western food for example if im making a potato filling sandwich i would add small chopped onions and different types of spices snd cook it a bit (ofc the potato is boiled and mashed before just cooking it to get the spices cooked) and wallah you have an amazing potato filling that everyone would crave , i like to add a cheese slice too and tamrind and mint chutney are optional , i generally dont add them cuz i either like to make them in big batches or not make them at all and if i make a big batch ik i aint gonan finish it

text: Its one of those things where even very simple versions are really good so its often just not worth paying for the higher quality ingredients or more complex recipes because it wint taste that much /better/. Im saying this as a 3rd generation italian immigrant (grandpa immegrated to the US so i didnt learn the language but do have all the family recipes), prego from the grocery store is almost as good as homemade sauce and if im being lazy i will absolutely just add spices to that and my family has never noticed. Theres certain things that are definitely better if made by an experienced chef but the vast majority of it can be slapped together for less money and taste about as good. Its not worth paying $50 for something marginally better than the $15 version

text: I just want to say this video is incredibly accurate. After my parents passed away I had to step up from just basic ‚Äúheating things up‚Äù to actual cooking. The first place I started was Italian cuisine because it‚Äôs know to have Great fucking flavour yet only use simple basic but quality ingredients. The cooking methods are straightforward and very easy. In no time at all I was able to make almost every Italian pasta meal to the same standard as the Italian restaurants near me. And for the record I avoided cooking one of my favourite meals (butter chicken and garlic Nan bread) simply because I knew damn well how much more complicated and difficult Indian food is to make. Neither one tastes better than the other but one is GREAT for beginner cooks and the other is difficult and much more technical. Yet Indian food is still way cheaper here in UK than any other food

text:
As an italian, I absolutely agree, italian food is overrated. It's just simple food anyone can make, and honestly? Most of it doesn't even taste good to begin with. Carbonara is one of the worst pastas i've ever had, it's disgusting unless you make it "wrong" by adding heavy cream.

Now, my family is from brazil, so I eat brazilian food at home. Ever had brazilian food? It's the best, just the best. Especially when made by a grandma lmao
We season our food perfectly, we have like 4 dishes all together, we love meat, churrasco (our barbecue), feijoada my god feijoada is amazing. And there are some dishes that can't be made easily in other countries, like Caldo Verde, because one of the vegetables essential for it is impossible to find in italy.
 AAAND, try it before you criticize it, brazilian pizza is the best. That's it. You have to try it for yourself because you will agree, unless you like thin pizza with more tomato sauce than toppings like italian pizza is ü§¢

text:
‚Äã¬†@jasonvargas7564¬†He's talking about Italian food, but he made something an Italian would NEVER make. This isn't Italian cuisine.

What he SHOULD have done, had he wanted to show something Italian, would be to make the pesto (pine nuts and no lemon though) and have it with the pasta. 
After that, as a second dish, have the chicken with the cream sauce. This chicken recipe isn't really a traditional Italian dish as far as I know (looks more French to me), but it looks tasty enough, provided he doesn't add in the pesto. 

Having both dishes at the same time with the two sauces mixed together is as silly as putting your salad into your soup.

author: @willfromdse5748

text: It's a cultural thing. As Americans we associate Italy with great leaders, fine dining, fancy wine, decadent dishes, and so fourth. This is reflected in the atmosphere. Sure. Joes pizza is a small corner shack on a strip mall that has Alfredo. But any chain or big name Italian joint has an extravagant decor and building. Here, it's more about perception and atmosphere than the dishes complexity or cost of creation. However making certain pasta types and raviolis from scratch is hard and takes time. Some places the effort is there, some places it's not. But the main thing is that the food is delicious, and people don't like to do the work them selves. From shopping to cooking, it takes time. Most Americans work 50+ hours a week. The luxury of having a delicious meal(even a cheap easy one) prepared for you and served to you is why they pay the price.
author: @willfromdse5748

Italian here. I've been to the USA a few times and I think that Italian food is overhyped by some people, rather than overrated. I agree that most of the time actual Italian cooking is pretty simple. text:
As an Italian: our cuisine is based on quality of ingredients not quantity. It‚Äôs based on a few techniques that go from simple to complex. It‚Äôs a way to combine every single piece of the puzzle and elevate it to something that is way more than the sum of its parts.

Is this true for all of italian food? No, osso-buco alla milanese is stupid hard (at least imo), baking panettone is impossible without failing, and folding tortellini is a pain in the ass. There are many examples, but the common denominator is always great ingredients and restraint make good food.

As someone who grew up Italian-American with family members who ran a restaurant: I am appalled by the idea of paying thst much for pasta.

text: Scoffing at $30+ pasta because it is ‚Äúsimple‚Äù is like saying upscale steaks are overpriced because they are simply seasoned meat on a grill. It‚Äôs kind of true but the price tag is somewhat justified when you consider how expensive certain ingredients such as pesto with actual pine nuts, pure olive oil and buffalo mozzarella (at least in the USA). Restaurants charge not only rent and ingredients but also time and skill. Simplicity means there is a larger margin for failure without spices and sugar to cover up bad cooking especially when you don‚Äôt have fresh herbs, tomatoes, garlic and vegetables as well as the skill to cut and cook them. Indeed being able to cut and cook whole fresh ingredients is by far the most important aspect of Italian cooking. Btw in my experience of cooking butter chicken, using whole spices from a local west Asian grocery store (especially if you blend your own garam masala)  and actually marinating and grilling the chicken beforehand can put your murgh makhani ahead of 95 percent of Indian restaurants in America. Most white person recipes and restaurants only use basic spices or watered down sauces and don‚Äôt marinate and grill the chicken to save time and money.

text:
¬†@nabkill0134¬†- facts.  Authentic Indian and Mexican food is really really good.  And if you have quality Chinese food, it can be excellent (and I really don‚Äôt like Chinese food).  

Can honestly say that all of my favorite restaurants in America are NOT Italian.  Real fine dining in America is French anyway, it‚Äôs not Italian.  It‚Äôs just that Italian restaurants in America are expensive for the Americanized version of Italian you get.  French fine dining in America is at least $200/person (and that‚Äôs no Michelin stars) so most people don‚Äôt even have it on their radar.

I make Italian food at home for my husband and son (it‚Äôs their favorite).  We make fresh pasta from scratch.  I‚Äôve made short rib ragu with homemade pappardelle, cacio pepe (as a quick lunch), spaghetti and meatballs regularly because we have young kids.  So because of this I can‚Äôt justify going to an expensive American Italian restaurant.  I‚Äôd rather just make it at home.

American Italian food is over sauced anyway.  I‚Äôve spoken to some native Italians here and they also hate Americanized Italian food.  The noodle is supposed to be the highlight in pasta dishes.  Fresh made pasta has a springy al dente.  The sauce is just a slight complimentary flavor for the pasta.  Americanized Italian food in American Italian restaurants have overcooked pasta that is over sauced.  And the pasta is rarely ever fresh.
author: @francestaylor9156

text:
Americanized Italian food really is overpriced for what you get.  It‚Äôs like going to those gringo Mexican restaurants where the food is bland but they have all-night margaritas which is why so many Americans eat there.  I figure Americanized Italian food is like that when comparing it to actual Italian food.

Even though Italian is my husband‚Äôs favorite, he‚Äôd 1000% rather make it at home than go out for it.  He knows we make it better at home than at the American Italian restaurants.  We make fresh pasta at home.  Already 100x better.
author: @francestaylor9156

text: ‚Äã¬†@HnyElf¬† laganon was NOT pasta. It was a pastry, most likely a flatbread. Lasagna is derived from the fact it's shaped like that pastry. Etruscans made testaroli, where they rolled a bread dough thin and cooked it like a pancake then covered it in sauce. That is the closest you get to modern Italian pasta until the middle ages. It's more likely Arab traders brought Persian pasta making to Italy, rather than China.
